comments.body: can use a default value here too

Different from `MakeDataset(...)` which returns a `Dataset` object, `RunDatasetOp()` executes the dataset kernel based on the input `DatasetParams` and returns the produced outputs as a tensor vector. It is helpful for some dataset operations that do not have an internal customized `Dataset` class (e.g. `ReduceDatasetOp`). This function can also be used to run other types of operations and produce outputs.
Can you add the information from this Github comment to the comment in code? The `ReduceDatasetOp` example is especially helpful for understanding how `RunDatasetOp` is intended to be used.
@aaudiber Good suggestion! The comment is enhanced by this commit (https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/33386/commits/e50ff7aac1f7f98fd103950dcdfbc53804a6b0d4).

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +778,782 @@  // customized `Dataset` class (e.g. `ReduceDatasetOp`).
  Status RunDatasetOp(const DatasetParams& dataset_params,
                      std::vector<Tensor>* outputs);

 protected:

comments.body: Add the virtual destructor for the base class, but did not add the destructor for the derived class in order to make the code concise (the destructor does not do anything). Please feel free to let me know if it is a good practice to add the destructor for the derived classes.
`const gtl::ArraySlice<T>` will cause the error `invalid conversion from 'const void*' to 'void*'` in some compiler, so `const` is removed here.
It is needed. The dataset test base provides some functions to create `RangeDataset` and `TensorSliceDataset`. Also, with it, the other unit test files do not need to import this header.
